Just to clarify my position above: the "but" was in opposition =
to Elliote's
point (which is to stay away from interfaces), not to testing =
real objects.
Obviously, testing real objects and using interfaces are not =
mutually
exclusive.

To summarize:

   - I tend to use real objects as much=
 as possible (avoiding mocks,
   using real DB connections, etc...).
   - I=
 use interfaces whenever it makes sense (if they make either my
   code or =
my tests easier to develop, read and maintain).
   - I don't let the assume=
d execution speed of a test stop me from
   writing that test in the first =
place.  I write the test, run it, and if it
   takes longer than it "should=
", then I move it into the "functional" or
   "slow" group.
